headline.main: John Chancellor, Professorial Anchor And Commentator at NBC, Is Deadat 68

results.snippet: John Chancellor, who covered 20 political conventions, a dozen space shots and a handful of wars in 41 years at NBC News, died yesterday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 68.         The cause was stomach cancer, said his daughter Mary Chancellor...
results.lead_paragraph: John Chancellor, who covered 20 political conventions, a dozen space shots and a handful of wars in 41 years at NBC News, died yesterday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 68. The cause was stomach cancer, said his daughter Mary Chancellor Gregory.

headline.main: No Shakes, No Quivers, No Doubts on the Rings

results.snippet: HE IS an Italian named Yuri, which is every bit as logical as a Russian named Giovanni. But Yuri Chechi's parents ultimately would look rather prescient for naming their infant son after the celebrated Soviet cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin.         Chechi...
results.lead_paragraph: HE IS an Italian named Yuri, which is every bit as logical as a Russian named Giovanni. But Yuri Chechi's parents ultimately would look rather prescient for naming their infant son after the celebrated Soviet cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin. Chechi would never orbit the earth, but like Gagarin, he would become a public figure. And, like Gagarin, he would become one by excelling with his feet well off the ground. Chechi is what is known in gymnastics as a "ringman," and a more appropriate term for the gregarious, red-haired Italian might be "ringmaster." He has won an unprecedented four consecutive world titles in the rings and is a heavy favorite to win the gold medal in Atlanta in the event.

headline.main: Golden Night for Melissanidis and Greece

results.snippet: Little more than three months ago, Ioannis Melissanidis was running through the streets of his native Thessaloniki with the Olympic torch in his hand and Olympic dreams in his head.         Tonight, Melissanidis became the first Greek gymnast in...
results.lead_paragraph: Little more than three months ago, Ioannis Melissanidis was running through the streets of his native Thessaloniki with the Olympic torch in his hand and Olympic dreams in his head. Tonight, Melissanidis became the first Greek gymnast in nearly a century to win an Olympic medal. He did it on the floor exercise, and what made it all the more stunning was that the color of the medal was gold.
